title: Low interest rates boost landlord cashflows
text:
Investors like Sydney-based Eddie Dilleen are now seeing their properties earn an income that is equal to or even higher than the holding cost – known as cashflow neutral or cashflow positive investment.

"The property I bought in Tuggerawong in NSW's Central Coast for $138,000 back in 2011 had a mortgage rate of 6.35 per cent, so even if it was earning $220 rent per week, I was still out of pocket by $65 after expenses," he said.

"Now that my mortgage rate had dropped to 3.5 per cent and with my rent rising to $300 per week, I am making $60 per week after cost."

The lower mortgage rates have also opened up more options for investors to find cashflow-positive property investments.

To get this, Select Residential Property head of research Jeremy Sheppard said that an investor will need a gross rental yield of about 4.75 per cent or higher.

More options

"This assumes an 80 per cent loan-to-value mortgage with a 4 per cent interest rate and another 1.5 per cent of the property’s value being lost to other expenses such as council rates, property management and repairs and maintenance," he said.

While this rules out most suburbs in Melbourne and Sydney, regional Victoria, such as Ballarat, and some suburbs within Sydney can still produce cashflow-positive investments, particularly for units.

Units in Rosehill, 23 kilometres west of Sydney CBD, are pulling off 5.2 per cent gross yield while Lakemba, in Sydney's south-west middle ring, is getting 5.09 per cent.

Mr Sheppard said that Perth and Adelaide have even more options, but Brisbane is offering the best potential for cashflow and capital growth.

"Almost every unit market in Brisbane is cashflow positive. But you don’t have to buy a unit to get a positive cashflow," he said.

"House markets such as the Gold Coast suburbs of Carrara, Nerang and Pacific Pines are currently getting an average of 5.3 per cent gross yields."

Mr Dilleen, who has already amassed a $4.6 million property portfolio across NSW, South Australia and Queensland, agreed that there are many options in Brisbane to get cashflow properties.

"I recently bought a three-bedroom house on a 600 square metre block for $285,000 in Moreton Bay, 53 kilometres north of the Brisbane CBD," he said.

"This house was rented for $325 per week, so it was getting 5.9 per cent gross yield that covered all my expenses and earning me $63 per week on top. This was cashflow positive from day one."
description: Despite the slowing rental market and higher prices squeezing rental yields, investors are now seeing their cashflow improve thanks to falling interest mortgage rates.
